importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when Diane Keaton's death was reported and confirmed by media outlets, marking the public awareness of her passing.
The release date of the film 'Annie Hall,' which marked the beginning of Diane Keaton's iconic career and earned her an Academy Award nomination.
The year in which Diane Keaton first appeared in the 'Godfather' film series, establishing her presence in major Hollywood productions.
The release date of the film 'First Wives Club,' a major box office success that highlighted Keaton's comedic and leading presence in mainstream cinema.
The release date of her directorial debut 'Unstrung Heroes,' showcasing her transition from acting to filmmaking as a producer and director.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The span of Diane Keaton's life and career, from her birth in 1946 to her death in 2025, reflects a full career trajectory across decades of Hollywood evolution.
The period from the 1970s to the 1990s represents the peak of her acting career, including major film successes and cultural influence in comedy and drama.
The 2000s to 2020s saw her continued presence in film, including roles in 'The Family Stone' and 'Book Club,' demonstrating longevity and relevance in modern cinema.

keyTakeAways: Diane Keaton, a celebrated Hollywood actress and fashion icon, died at age 79 from bacterial pneumonia.
She won an Academy Award for Best Actress in 1977 for her role in 'Annie Hall,' a film that showcased her unique comedic timing and gender-nonconforming style.
Keaton was known for her distinctive fashion sense, including the use of men's slacks, vests, and hats, which made her a trailblazer in fashion and a symbol of individuality.

She appeared in major films such as 'Godfather,' 'Looking for Mr. Goodbar,' 'Reds,' 'Baby Boom,' 'First Wives Club,' 'Marvin’s Room,' 'Something’s Gotta Give,' and 'The Family Stone,' demonstrating versatility across genres.
Keaton was not only an actress but also a producer and director, with credits including 'Unstrung Heroes' and 'Hanging Up,' and served as an executive producer on 'Maybe I Do' (2023).
She remained unmarried, citing her mother's example and a deep commitment to independence as key reasons for her personal choices.
She was survived by her two children, daughter Dexter and son Duke, whom she adopted in her 50s.
Her death was confirmed by producer Dori Rath and reported by People magazine and CNN, highlighting her enduring public profile.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Diane Keaton, a celebrated Hollywood actress, comedian, and fashion icon, has died at the age of 79 from bacterial pneumonia. Known for her distinctive comedic timing and gender-nonconforming style—most notably in the Academy Award-winning film 'Annie Hall'—she built a diverse film career spanning decades, appearing in major films such as 'Godfather,' 'First Wives Club,' 'Marvin’s Room,' and 'The Family Stone.' A trailblazer in both acting and fashion, Keaton also served as a producer and director, with credits including 'Unstrung Heroes' and 'Hanging Up.' She remained unmarried, citing her mother’s example and a commitment to independence. Keaton was admired by peers like Jane Fonda, Reese Witherspoon, and Steve Martin, and was featured in numerous films through the 2020s, including 'Book Club' and 'Summer Camp.' Her legacy reflects a unique blend of humor, personal integrity, and enduring cultural relevance in Hollywood.
title: Diane Keaton, ‘La-Dee-Da’ dame of Hollywood, dead at 79
